STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 6, 2023
JILL SCHREUDER
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - MUSKEGON
1720 PARK ST,
MUSKEGON, MI, 49441-2403
RE: License#: CB610201023
Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on July 6, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB610201023
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL SCHREUDER
Name of Agency: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
MUSKEGON
Agency Address: 1720 PARK ST
MUSKEGON, MI 49441-2403
Agency Telephone #: 2317264735
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
Two of nine employee files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as required.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238
(1) An agency shall develop a written plan and implement
the plan to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL
722.621, and known as the child protection law.
Two of six new employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency was
in compliance with the child protection law as the file lacked the 4624 form.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report.
Three of four special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) a physical examination every 14 months.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have timely periodic medical
examinations completed as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a safe, stable, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation that all information
required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers within the
timeframes outlined within the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed (2 of 32 service plans) did not have the Updated
Service Plan completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed
and updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a
copy provided to the youth.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth quarterly as
required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.

Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be
provided within two weeks of the child's placement date to the
following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult
re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.

• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom the
child is newly referred to and accepted for treatment or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment
while the foster care case is open, regardless of
placement. Subsequent medical passports are not
required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
aged 18 and older).
YAVFC youth/young adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary
foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been found to
produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A quality visit
is defined as one in which the caseworker:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.

• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate
way while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor, foster
parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the case of
placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Seven of eight foster care files reviewed (20 of 32 service plans) did not contain all of
the required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• FTM and TDM reports should be uploaded in the FTM tab.
• The date on document for uploaded documents should be accurate.
• Be sure to link all SWC to service plans.
• Upload certificate for CPR/First Aid.
• Upload Help Desk ticket information if SOP was impacted.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. A special evaluation initiated 9/12/2022 determined the foster parents allowed
the child to be around an individual that was not allowed contact. During the incident
the individual encouraged the youth to cut herself. The foster parents were
substantiated for abuse and neglect and now have a confirmed case. They were
given a 2nd provisional license. A 1st provisional was issued due to foster parents
not taking appropriate steps to lock up medication and youth took too many Tylenol
and needed medical treatment. The agency's findings and recommendation were
found to be appropriate, based on the information gathered during the investigation.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 6/29/2022 with a corrective action plan approved
on 7/28/2022. During the review the agency had ten violations. Seven citations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in a part, by
increased staff turnover.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s effort put forth in meeting requirements
during this review period. The Chief Administrator(CA) stated the previous year
CAP was effective but agency growth and training new staff during the past year
has impacted overall compliance.
The CA indicated that hiring a Foster Care Team Lead has been beneficial to staff.
In addition, the agency has revised the processes for training new staff, tracking
and supervisory monitoring in an effort to achieve compliance. The CA expressed
confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported coworkers
and supervisors are available when needed. Additionally, staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. There were no concerns identified.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
________7/6/2023_____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 6, 2023
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
